;kz.12(6B9t;LR@.c36m.text:
First Bifurcation

At this point the story splits into two different versions. Though the outcome is always the same. There is no happy end.

The story path is determined by the outcome of the "Make Toni Fly" game.

NhfHg1^#0e4z#eBz1i@g.text:
After the main story has ended, the viewer has a choice between three stories and an activities collection.

Due to time restrictions and to get the viewer to to engage once again with the story only two can be selected per viewing

=QWl-ylFw3O36rFE6q=b.text: setting variables to default values if they can not be set in the script. The "viewed Stories variable, if set in the script using it, would create an infinite loop.

?B-B=]Py77rfA4j:u9j_.text:
"start_story_ALL" Script

This script triggers the first user interaction where they can chose which main story to view by vaguely indicating what kind of story they can expect from their choice.

Only one main story can be chosen due to time constraint and for viewers to start this program multiple times to view all parts of this story, like a video game that has to be multiple times, this digital story has to therefor be viewed and interacted with multiple times.

@;e}|/zClXl/SHKpVw7u.text:
"hide_ALL" script

This script hides all sprites with one script.

This ensures the screen in completely wiped clean and brought back to the digital story's starting point.

The script helps during script writing and testing time when all sprites need to be removed with the push of a button.

At one point it had been incorporated into other scripts so that just one block of code was required instead of using multiple blocks to hide multiple scripts at the same time, but once again it triggers the unusual behaviour of scratch to not execute scripts in full (e.g. not changing backdrops). Hence this code is no longer called by any scripts.

EJCUhf4_.rwiFJB]]A(}.text:
Game Variables 

These variables are used with most games. They are either set to constant values or default values that are changed during the game.

"currentGame" is used to inform sprites that are reused which game script is currently being executed so that the right scripts are triggered.

"winner" indicates if a game has been won or lost and displays the appropriate screen.

"count_countdown" is one of the counting variables. In this case it counts how far the countdown has progressed so that scripts know when to start or end.

"state_game" indicates if the game is ongoing or come to its end. This informs scripts if it is to continue its game play part or end the game.

3#1m`Z*yKl?@E*OyE],P.text:
NOTES
Comments

Comments addressing a script, in general, are placed at the top. The width of the comment box is set to the width of the first code block. This is to show it belongs to that specific script and to keep the code neat and tidy.

Comments regarding parts of the script are placed next to that part.

Comments that regards multiple scripts span multiple code columns indicating that they not only apply to the code they are placed above or beside.

Each comment has a heading to further indicate what it is addressing.

Please note, that in the rare cases where the inbuilt commenting on blocks is used that the position of these comments will change with each loading of the script. This is another of the many bugs in Scratch.



Code Placement

**Support scripts**, scripts that are used in multiple instances or scripts, are placed at the top of the code sheet.

On the main sheet (where backdrops can be accessed, list order set, and edited), all scripts regarding a single story are placed below the main script. E.g. a story script might be interrupted with a game. The game code is held separately in its own script and this script is then placed below the main script.

The different story scripts are placed next to each other.

Where bifurcation occurs the story split is shown by placing the story continuation scripts next to each other indicating at which point the bifurcation takes place.




Hacks

This code contains multiple hacks to work around bugs found with Scratch. These hacks are commented on. One unnecessary hack, for which I did not have the time to remove, related to timing has been explained in my reflection. My animation could have been so much smoother - sigh.



Bugs

The following are bugs I've run into (and can remember) during my work on this digital story project.

* The main bug I had issues with was the non-execution of code blocks in a script. The script would run to the end but parts of the code would not be executed (e.g. switching backdrops or costumes). This bug is also not consistent throughout all scripts, even if they use the same code blocks (code needs to be repeated if they are to be used in multiple sprites (sometimes it is better to keep the script from becoming overly complex and hence more difficult to read and it helps to keep better control on where and when bugs are triggered).

* Inconsistency of rescaling uploaded images (backdrops and sprites). This means that some sprites, although they have the exact same size, have costumes that vary in size and hence need to be resized when the change to them occurs. 

* When using the graphics editor one might require the resizing of an image, this can only be done with vector images. Once the change had been done the image needs to be returned to a bitmap or the program can no longer be stored on the Scratch server.

* The sound editor is very buggy, sometimes not working at all or once used (not always but in most cases, could not narrow down what triggers the bug) the program can no longer be stored on the Scratch server.

* There is also occasional choppiness both in the animation of sprites or playing of the sound. 

* Inconsistency in scrolling sprites beyond the edge. This leads (far too often) to the sprite still being displayed, requiring the additional introduction of a "hide" block although the sprite might be used again in the same sprite requiring a repeat of inserting the "show" block.

The "state_game" and "winner" Variables

The "state_game" variable tells the script if the end of the game has been reached. "1" it the value for a finished game.

The "winner" variable tells the script if the task was successfully completed. If so the value "1" is set.

"state_click" Variable

This variable is to record if a click/selection has been made, as there is no way to say "if no clicks on these two sprites, then do this." A work around is to set a default value of "no clicks occurred" which is "0" and change it to "1" if a click event does.

MESSAGE: What was so difficult about this task?
All you had to do is click on one of the arrows.
All actions have consequences.
You are now not able to view either of the main stories.
Hehehe, smart kid, not always following the rules, trying out new things.
But they have to still learn about consequences to our behaviour.
Maybe they are smart enough to find the other Easter eggs.
Ahh hahaha.
I'm a happy camper now.
Hmm...what can I say without being rude?
Hello! Thanks for popping in, please come again.

U0;czbwlR@GSq_M@jxYx.text:
"count_pages" Variable

In there is one different state, a different costume, the sprite switches to and this costume has information that counts as a page.

This variable needs to be used at this point to ensure that when the sprite is clicked it always switches between the two states of just being a sun or displaying the the sun with information.

The start value is set to "0". 

This is additional information that a user can stumble upon by accident or by a mind of a hacker clicking on everything and everywhere to see if this causes a change in the game. This curiosity need to be nourished.

77?XyC]035*^[0t5rAao.text:
Stopping the Countdown on Reaching Game Objective

Need to reimplement the stop early functionality.

After each count the script will check for current "count_countdown" to see if it is zero. If it is "state_game" will be changed to "1" so that the game controlling script knows it's time to display the game over messages.

za$34[?Tuxn:SSto7XJn.text:
Speaking Animation Control Variables

To control the animation of Keith to give the impression of speech (moving lips/mouth) the scripts need two variables.

The "count_speakTime" variable keeps tabs on how long the speaking movement has been. It counts the time for both when lips are an are not moving.

The "speak_time" variable is the time set for how long the movement is to last.

{#.,)v~?HM{nhJLk3nh~.text:
"animate_keithSpeaking" Script

This script controls the lip movement of Keith to give the impression of the character speaking.

It has four costumes for this purpose.

Each costume switch is executed three times consecutively, this hack allows for finer time control, allowing getting around the "wait"'s block limited capability due to just accepting integer values.

R1Xk8gR.DFbjJB.)e$Nj.text:
"animate_keithStopsSpeaking" Script

This script should have been named differently. animate_keithNotSpeaking would have been a better choice to make the code more legible.

This script is required as the "wait" block provided by Scratch only executes integer values, which are often values that are too large to display an accurate timing for lip movement control. This script allows finer control of the time the lips do not move.

For time control this function uses the same variables as the "animate_keithSpeaking" script.

^(`_;SzVAj9hU,Xly!8C.text:
"animate_keithSpeaksPart1" and "animate_keithSpeakingBackInTheDayPart3" Scripts

These scripts control the speaking illusion created by animating Keith to seemingly move his lips.

These functions have been created for the movement to work as placing the instructions in the story script gets them ignored so that the animation is not displayed. Why this should be the case I don't know

.E*1d[tZSEEdHc;}fWZ^.text:
"display_keithHelpAToni" Script

This script controls the introduction to the "Help A Toni" story. It allows the viewer to change his mind on viewing this story. Though it does count towards the number of stories viewed.

Having this interaction also allows reminding the viewer of the ethical need to take action to change one's behaviour when dealing with plastic bags.

To make this option more productive, it now displays a page suggesting an interesting science experiment to conduct, which might
get the viewer to rethink if he should help Toni or not.

;P.?liJ6@+7JkX~f!4x}.text:
"answer" Variable

There are two valid answers yes or no. If a wrong answer is provided the answer check needs to be performed again until a correct answer is given.

Once a valid option has been chosen the value is set to 1 to indicate to this part of the script it no longer has to run and the repeat cycle can come to an end.

"viewed_X" Variable

These variables tell other scripts if the sub-sub-story has already been displayed or not. Any sub-sub-story already viewed no longer appears on the selection screen in the "Help a Toni" sub-story.

If set to "0" it has not yet been viewed and "1" says it has been viewed.

"count_views" Variable

In this case the "count_views" variable is set to "1" to tell the main script that the sub-story "Help a Toni" has been viewed. We allow viewers to skip the need of having to watch all other sub-sub-stories.

!,|n5+4z9?Jc}`u;VR#L.text:
This script uses two numbers to control how far the wheel spins.

"count_fields" counts how many fields have been touched.

"randomNumber" holds a randomly chosen number between 16 and 80. This means the wheel spins at least twice and at most ten times.

Then the random number is checked if it can be divided by two without a remainder, if so a fact is presented. If not a friendly message is displayed.

hBsfwTgW!dGi*VyUIH}C.text:
Variables Set To Start Values

"count_turns" keeps tabs on how often the player has spun the wheel. Every player gets four spins to learn a fact.

"randomNumberControl" keeps tabs on how often a random number has been picked for displaying and selecting a fact to display.

yRKDywDIm.qp=.[G8m!p.text:
"facts" List Set To Start Values

A method is needed to ensure that every fact is only displayed once or a viewer might be stuck with a single fact being repeated. For this a list is used.

The list is populated at the start of the script with all other variables that need to be set to a start value.

After a fact is presented to the viewer that fact gets removed from the list.

prRX`z2%_B_g!OiyZq)a.text:
We create a random number from the range of one to four. Depending on how many facts have already been displayed determines how many facts are available to pick from by random choice.

"randomNumberControl" counts how many facts have been displayed. 

The script tests if the amount of displayed facts exceeds the number of available facts, if so the script is terminated.

yVp$:WcLwphiDa*+K]#n.text:
"clearGeffects} Variable

This variable informs the spin button if it can be activated again for the next spin. This i s the case when all parts of the game are back in place at which point all graphic effects are removed. When removed the variable is set to "1".

QS%H6DYL3q+~CqdOQ~qa.text: Using this block construct to imitate sliding in block but with finer control over the glide time.

XcBC1hY;sqvoHu|Qax#f.text:
"clearedGeffects" Variable

The button stays in a depressed state until the game can continue again. This is when the fading has been taken away and all elements of the game are fully displayed. When this happens the "clearedGeffects" variable is set to 1 indicating that all graphical effects have been removed allowing for the game to proceed.
